body.p: Apache FOP provides an Ant task for automating the document build process.

section.title: Description
section.p: The FOP Ant task will convert XSL-FO documents to PDF, PS, PCL etc. output (see Output formats for available formats).
To call FOP tasks within Ant, first add a FOP task definition to your Ant build file. One method of defining the task is as follows:
section.source:
<property name="fop.home" value="....path to your FOP HOME directory..."/>
<taskdef name="fop" classname="org.apache.fop.tools.anttasks.Fop"> <classpath> <fileset dir="${fop.home}/lib"> <include name="*.jar"/> </fileset> <fileset dir="${fop.home}/build"> <include name="fop.jar"/> <include name="fop-hyph.jar" /> </fileset> </classpath> </taskdef>
section.p: Then create FOP tasks within your Ant build file, using the FOP task parameters listed below.

application/postscript

application/x-afp, application/vnd.ibm.modcap

Base directory to resolve relative references (e.g., graphics files) within the FO document.
No, for single FO File entry, default is to use the location of that FO file.

For fileset usage only. A value of true specifies using the location of each .fo file as the base directory for resolving relative file references located within that .fo file. A value of false specifies using the value of basedir for all files within the fileset, or just the current working directory if basedir is not specified.
User configuration file (same as the FOP "-c" command line option).

Logging level
Possible values: error, warn, info, verbose, debug. Currently doesn't work in FOP Trunk!!!
Controls whether the names of the files that are processed are logged (true) or not (false). Currently doesn't work in FOP Trunk!!!
FileSets are used to specify multiple XSL-FO files to be rendered.

section.title: Examples
section.p: The following example converts a single XSL-FO file to a PDF document:
section.source: <target name="generate-pdf" description="Generates a single PDF file"> <fop format="application/pdf" fofile="c:\working\foDirectory\foDocument.fo" outfile="c:\working\pdfDirectory\pdfDocument.pdf" /> </target>
section.p: This example converts all XSL-FO files within an entire directory to PostScript:
section.source: <target name="generate-multiple-ps" description="Generates multiple PostScript files"> <fop format="application/postscript" outdir="${build.dir}" messagelevel="debug"> <fileset dir="${fo.examples.dir}"> <include name="*.fo"/> </fileset> </fop> </target>
